questions.question: Which one of the following is essential for preventing tooth decay?
questions.solution:
• Nutrients are necessary for the growth, energy, repair, and maintenance of the body.
  • Nutrients are classified as Macronutrients and Micronutrients.
  • Carbohydrates, Calories, and Proteins are an example of Macronutrients.


Micronutrients:

  • Micronutrients are the elements required by us in small quantities.
  • Iron, cobalt, chromium, iodine, copper, zinc, molybdenum are some of the micronutrients.
  • Deficiency of any of the nutrients affects growth and development.
  • They play a major role in the metabolic activities of the body.
  • ​These include vitamins and minerals.



Thus, Flouride is essential for preventing tooth decay.

questions.question: Deficiency of Iodine causes-
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Goitre.Key Points 

  • Deficiency of Iodine causes Goitre.
  • Deficiency of iodine can result in a range of disabilities and disorders such as goitre, hypothyroidism, cretinism, abortion, stillbirths, mental retardation, and psychomotor defects.
    • Defects in which there is a slow down in thought process and a reduction of physical movements in an individual.
  • Iodine deficiency is the most common cause of thyroid enlargement and goitre.
  • Within a goitre, nodules can develop.
  • Patients with a large goitre may experience symptoms of choking, especially when lying down, and difficulty swallowing and breathing.

Important Points 

Iodine:

  • Iodine is a vital micro-nutrient for the optimal mental and physical development of human beings.
  • In 1992, India made fortification of salt with iodine mandatory, for direct human consumption.
  • In 2011, the Supreme Court also mandated universal iodization for the control of iodine deficiencies.
  • A recent initiative in this regard named Jeevan Bindi (an iodine patch designed like a regular bindi) was started to help one lakh tribal women in north-west Maharashtra battle iodine deficiency as these tribals did not consume iodized salt.

Additional Information

questions.question: If&nbsp;the&nbsp;mother&#39;s&nbsp;diet&nbsp;is&nbsp;qualitatively&nbsp;and/or&nbsp;quantitatively&nbsp;inadequate,&nbsp;it will:
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Limit foetal growth and development.

Key Points

  • When a pregnant woman's diet lacks either in quality (i.e., not getting the right types or balance of nutrients) or quantity (i.e., not getting enough food), it can potentially limit fetal growth and development.
  • The fetus relies entirely on the mother for its nutritional needs, and insufficient intake of nutrients from the mother's diet can restrict the supply of these vital elements to the developing fetus.
  • Examples of key nutrients in a healthy prenatal diet include:
  1. Proteins: Essential for the growth of fetal tissue, including the brain. Also vital for increasing breast and uterine tissue during pregnancy.
  2. Folic acid: Helps form the neural tube and can prevent major birth defects of the baby’s brain and spine.
  3. Iron: Needed to make more blood supply oxygen to the baby. Iron deficiency can lead to preterm delivery, low birth weight, and infant mortality.
  4. Calcium: For the baby's bone development.

questions.question: What is the estimate of the average protein intake an adult person should consume?
options: 0.5 grams of protein/kg body weight per day
0.6 grams of protein/kg body weight per day
0.7 grams of protein/kg body weight per day
0.8 grams of protein/kg body weight per day
questions.solution:
Concept:

Nutrients:

  • The food we consume breaks down to simpler products before it is absorbed and utilised by the body.
  • These simpler substances are called nutrients.
  • Our body utilises nutrients for building and repairing, obtaining energy and for protection from diseases.

Explanation:

Protein:

  • Proteins are called building blocks of our body.
  • About 20 per cent of our body weight comes from proteins.
  • Proteins are essential for the growth and repair of muscle and other body tissues.
  • Proteins are made of amino acids that contain the elements carbon, hydrogen, oxygen and nitrogen.
  • We obtain proteins from the animal as well as vegetable sources.
  • An adult should consume 0.8 grams of protein/kg body weight per day according to the dietary reference intake report for micronutrients.

Thus, 0.8 grams of protein/kg body weight per day is the estimate of the average protein intake an adult person should consume.

Additional InformationCarbohydrate:

  • Carbohydrates are the main source of energy for our bodies.
  • There are three major categories of carbohydrates, starch, sugar and cellulose.
  • Our body breaks down sugar and starch into glucose to provide energy.
  • An adult should consume 225 to 325 grams of carbohydrate /kg body weight per day according to the dietary reference intake report for micronutrients.

Fat:

  • Fats and oils are concentrated sources of energy.
  • Fats are substances that our body stores for future use.
  • These are classified as simple lipids (e.g. triglycerides), compound lipids (e.g. phospholipids), and derived lipids (e.g. cholesterol).
  • An adult should consume 44 grams to 77 grams of fat/kg body weight per day.

questions.question: Which of the following nutrients provides heat and strength?
questions.solution:
Concept:

  • Nutrients are the chemical substances present in food and are responsible for nourishing the body.
  • The common nutrients in our food are:
    • Carbohydrates
    • Proteins
    • Fats
    • Vitamins
    • Minerals
    • Fibre
    • Water
  • Carbohydrates, proteins, fats, and oils are macronutrients.
  • Minerals and vitamins are called micronutrients.

Explanation:

  • Based on the functions that are performed by various types of food items available, they can be broadly divided into
    three groups.
  • The three food groups are:​
    • Energy giving food:
      • They provide heat and strength to the body.
      • Carbohydrates and fats belong to this category.
      • Food sources are cereals, fats, and sugar.
    • Bodybuilding Food:
      • These are needed for muscle building and repairing worn-out cells and tissues.
      • Proteins belonging to this category.
      • Food sources are meat, rajma, pulses, etc.
    • Protective food:
      • Vitamins and minerals are called protective food.
      • These are important for the regulation of body processes and help our body in fighting diseases.

Thus, carbohydrates provide heat and strength.

questions.question: Deficiency of Vitamin C is causes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Vitamins
    • ​They are organic compounds that help in performing the biological functions of a living organism.
    • It is a vital nutrient that should be included in our daily diet in the required quantity.
    • They are referred to as organic compounds and are required in very small amounts, hence, they are mentioned as micronutrients.
    • They perform vital functions and an essential role in our body functions such as metabolism, immunity and digestion.
  • Vitamins are of two types:
    • Fat-soluble – which are dissolved in fat
    • Water-soluble – which are dissolved in water
  • Vitamin C
    • It is a water-soluble vitamin that plays a vital role in repairing, production, regeneration, and maintenance of tissues, bones, blood vessels, and skin.
    • It is a powerful antioxidant, which helps in protecting against heart-related disorders, a variety of cancers and neutralises the effects of nitrites.
    • It also absorbs iron and prevents scurvy, and decreases LDL or bad cholesterol and triglycerides.
  • Scurvy:
    • It is a disease caused by a severe deficiency of vitamin C, hence it is also called chronic vitamin C deficiency disorder. Hence option 3 is correct.
    • Following are the symptoms of Scurvy: Anaemia, Bleeding gums and gingivitis, Bruised hair follicles and skin hemorrhages, and Swollen joints.
    • Oral vitamin C supplements and foods containing vitamin C help treat scurvy.

Thus, deficiency of vitamin C causes Scurvy.

Additional Information

Below is the table  list of Vitamin and Deficiency Diseases:

questions.question: Intake of protein less than 0.4 to 0.6gm/kg of body weight per day is considered as:
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Low protein intake.

Key Points

  • Incidence: A pattern of consuming less than 0.4 to 0.6g of protein per kg of body weight per day is considered low protein intake.
  • This may occur due to poor diet, certain disorders, or by choice in certain dietary lifestyles.
  • Basic Role of Protein: Protein is one of the fundamental macronutrients essential for a host of biological functions such as building and repair of body tissues, production of enzymes and hormones, and forming antibodies.
  • Protein Intake Recommendations: The Dietary Reference Intake (DRI) for protein is a minimum of 0.8g per kg of body weight per day for adults.
  • However, the needs can vary depending on a person's age, sex, level of physical activity, and overall health condition.
  • Effects of Low Protein Intake: Low protein intake over time may lead to symptoms like edema, thin and brittle hair, lethargy, skin problems, loss of muscle mass, increased risk of bone fractures, and in severe cases, kwashiorkor, a severe form of malnutrition.
  • At-Risk Populations: Those at risk of low protein intake include the elderly, those with eating disorders, vegans and vegetarians not adequately balancing their diets, people living in poverty, and people with specific dietary restrictions due to other health conditions.
  • Supplementation and Dietary Adjustments: In case of low protein intake, diet modifications are usually suggested as the first line of treatment.
  • This could include increasing consumption of high-protein foods and/or using protein supplements.
  • High-Protein Foods: Foods rich in protein include fish, lean meats, eggs, dairy products, legumes, nuts and seeds.
  • There are also good sources of protein in some grains and vegetables.
  • Monitoring Protein Intake: Regularly monitoring protein intake can prevent low protein intake scenarios.
  • Food journals, nutritional labels, and in some cases consultation with a dietitian or nutritionist, can all be useful tools.
  • Potential Consequences on Long-term Health: Chronic low protein intake can impact overall health in the long term, causing growth issues in children, challenges in healing and recovering from wounds or illnesses, decreased immunity, and general weakness or fatigue.
  • Importance of Balanced Diet: Beyond just protein, a balanced diet providing adequate portions of all macronutrients (protein, carbohydrates, fats) and micronutrients (vitamins and minerals) is crucial for overall health and well-being.

questions.question: In which method of cooking is food heated slowly over a source of heat and cooked by high heat and air convection depending on the position of the food in relation to the fire?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Spit-roasting.

Key Points

  • In spit-roasting, the food is skewered on a spit and rotated slowly over a source of heat.
  • The heat source can be an open flame or hot coals, and the food is cooked by the radiant heat and hot air that surrounds it.
  • Spit-roasting is often used for large cuts of meat, such as whole chickens or pigs, and can result in a crispy, flavorful exterior and juicy interior.
  • This method of cooking requires constant attention and turning off the spit to ensure even cooking.

Additional InformationBraising

  • Braising involves cooking food slowly in a covered pot with a small amount of liquid, such as broth or wine.
  • The food is first seared on the stovetop to develop flavor, then simmered in the liquid for a long period of time.
  • This method is often used for tough cuts of meat, as the slow cooking and liquid help to tenderize the meat.
  • Braising can result in a flavorful, tender dish with a rich sauce.

Poaching

  • Poaching involves cooking food in a liquid that is just below boiling point.
  • The liquid can be water, broth, or other flavorful liquids, and the food is typically submerged in the liquid.
  • This method is often used for delicate foods, such as fish or eggs, as it is a gentle cooking method that helps to retain moisture and flavor.
  • Poaching can result in a tender, moist dish with a subtle flavor.

Stewing

  • Stewing involves cooking food slowly in a covered pot with a larger amount of liquid than braising.
  • The food is typically cut into smaller pieces and simmered in the liquid for a long period of time.
  • This method is often used for tougher cuts of meat, as the slow cooking and liquid help to tenderize the meat.
  • Stewing can result in a flavorful, tender dish with a rich sauce.

questions.question: Which of the following nutrients is available mainly in apples?&nbsp;
questions.solution:
The correct answer is K.Key Points

  • Potassium (K) is the nutrient that is available mainly in apples.
  • Apples are a good source of potassium, which is an essential mineral required for various bodily functions such as heart health, nerve function, and muscle contraction.
  • Apples are also a good source of fiber, vitamin C, and antioxidants that can help promote overall health.

Additional Information

  • Cobalt is required in trace amounts for the production of vitamin B12 in the body.
    • Vitamin B12, which aids in the synthesis of red blood cells, contains cobalt. 
  • Apples are low in sodium and can be a good addition to a low-sodium diet.
    • The body needs sodium, an essential nutrient, to keep bodily fluids balanced and to maintain healthy muscles and neurons.
  • Sulfur is required for the production of certain amino acids and proteins in the body.
    • Sulfur is necessary for the body to assemble and repair DNA and shield cells from harm that could result in life-threatening conditions like cancer.

questions.question: Anemia is caused by shortage of :
questions.solution:
Concept:

  • Diseases can be caused due to various underlying reasons. 
  • Proper food and diet are necessary for fast recovery from any diseases.
  • A doctor advises different types of food during different diseases.

Explanation:

Anaemia:

  • Anaemia means having less ‘haemoglobin’ or iron in the blood.
  • Haemoglobin is an iron-rich protein that is present in the blood and is responsible for transporting oxygen from the lungs to the tissue.
  • Due to lack of iron, there is a decrease in the level of haemoglobin because of which, oxygen cannot be properly circulated throughout the body.
  • Anaemia disease is a result of deficiency of Iron.
  • Medicines are taken for strength.
  • People should eat jaggery, amla and green leafy vegetables because these have iron.
  • The desired limit for haemoglobin in a healthy individual should be 
    • For men: 13.5 to 17.5 gm/dl 
    • For women: 12.0 to 15.5 gm/dl 

Thus, the main cause of Anemia in human beings is the deficiency of iron.

Additional Information 

Deficiency of protein:

  • Deficiency diseases: Kwashiorkor
  • Sources: beans, dal, meat, soybean

Deficiency of calcium:

  • Deficiency diseases: Osteoporosis
  • Sources: Amla, milk, green vegetables and dairy products

Deficiency of vitamin A:

  • Deficiency diseases: Night-blindness, Hyperkeratosis, and Keratomalacia
  • Sources: Orange, ripe yellow fruits, leafy vegetables, carrots, pumpkin, squash, spinach, liver

questions.question: <span style="">Most common nutritional deficiency disease observed among adolescent girls in India is -</span>
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Anaemia.

Key Points

  • Anaemia is a condition in which there is a lack of enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to the body's tissues.
  • Having anaemia, also referred to as low haemoglobin, can make a person feel tired and weak.

Types of anaemia:

  • Aplastic anaemia
  • Iron deficiency anaemia
  • Sickle cell anaemia
  • Thalassemia
  • Vitamin deficiency anaemia

Iron deficiency anaemia is the most common type of anaemia in adolescents

  • Iron deficiency anaemia signs and symptoms may include:
  • Extreme fatigue
  • Weakness
  • Pale skin
  • Chest pain, fast heartbeat or shortness of breath
  • Headache, dizziness or lightheadedness
  • Cold hands and feet

Additional Information

  1.  Aplastic anaemia is a condition that occurs when your body stops producing enough new blood cells. The condition leaves you fatigued and more prone to infections and uncontrolled bleeding. A rare and serious condition, aplastic anaemia can develop at any age.
  2. Pernicious anaemia is a type of vitamin B12 anaemia. The body needs vitamin B12 to make red blood cells. Common causes of pernicious anaemia include Weakened stomach lining (atrophic gastritis) An autoimmune condition in which the body's immune system attacks the actual intrinsic factor protein or the cells in the lining of the stomach that make it.
  3. Hemolytic anaemia occurs when you have a low number of red blood cells due to too much hemolysis in the body. Certain conditions can cause hemolysis to happen too fast or too often, including the following: Autoimmune conditions. Bone marrow failure. Complications from blood transfusions.

questions.question: The yolk or yellow protein makes up about _______ percent of the liquid weight of the egg.
questions.solution:
Concept

  • Eggs are the reproductive body produced by chickens.
  •  It contains albumin and yolk.
  • Eggs are an excellent source of proteins.
  • Proteins obtained from egg help in bodybuilding and repairing the body tissue.

Explanation

33%

  • The egg has different parts.
  • Namely shell, albumin, Yolk, Chalaza, germinal disc, etc.
  • Albumen is also known as egg white.
  • It makes up 67% of liquid weight.
  • The yolk makes up 33% of liquid weight.
  • A large egg contains 6 gm of protein and 5 gm of healthy fat.
  • It is rich in iron, vitamins, and minerals.

Thus, the yolk makes up about 33% of the egg's liquid weight.

questions.question: Children with pot belly is an indicative of which type of disease?
questions.solution:
Content:

  • Diseases are primarily diagnosed by symptoms.
  • Each disease or health condition has different symptoms, which can help in diagnosis. 

Explanation:

  • Kwashiorkor is a PEM (Protein Energy Malnutrition) syndrome., which is highly characterized by a pot belly.
  • Potbelly is a condition of a rotund stomach or when the belly protrudes out in a round shape, resembling a pot.
  • This condition occurs due to a lack of protein in the diet,
    • which affects the balance and distribution of fluids in the body and
    • often leads to a swollen belly. 

Thus, children with a pot belly are indicative of symptoms of Kwashiorkor.

Additional Information

questions.question: <p>How many milligrams of calcium do teens aged 13-15 need?</p>
questions.solution:
Concept:

  • The body requires the mineral calcium in many different places.
  • Its primary function is to create healthy, strong bones and teeth, which account for 99% of the calcium in the body.
  • Among other crucial tasks, calcium aids in blood pressure regulation and the movement of our muscles.

Explanation:

  • The key mineral that strengthens bones is calcium, and this is crucial during adolescence when teens are going through their development spurt.
  • People lose bone mass during the course of their lifetimes, reaching their peak bone density in adolescence.
  • While white beans, broccoli, and tofu are examples of "non-dairy" foods that are rich in calcium, whole milk and other dairy products are also a great sources of the mineral.
  • Teenagers of age 13-15 require a minimum of 800 milligrams of calcium. 
  • Green vegetables like spinach, kale, cabbage, turnips, and collard greens are great providers of calcium.

Thus, 800 milligrams of calcium are required by teens of age 13-15 years daily.

questions.question: The nutrients that provide &#39;protection against diseases&#39; are
questions.solution:
Concept:

Nutrition:

  • Nutrition is the sum of the processes by which an organism takes in, metabolizes, and utilizes food substances.
  • Nutrients are organic or inorganic substances that help in our survival and in maintaining proper health.
  • The term nutrition is related to our food intake and dietary patterns and utilization of protein, carbohydrate, fat, vitamins, and minerals to maintain our health.
  • Food can be classified into three categories based on its functions which are energy-giving food, protective food, and body-building food.

Explanation:​

Protective foods:

  • ​These are rich in minerals and vitamins.
  • They help in the regulation of internal metabolism in the body.
  • They provide protection against diseases.
  • Examples are green leafy vegetables, fruits, amla, guava, citrus, oranges, etc.

Key Points

Vitamins:

  • ​Vitamins are organic substances that we require in adequate quantities for good health.
  • Vitamins are divided into two groups–
    • fat-soluble vitamins (Vitamins A, D, E, and K)
    • water-soluble vitamins (Vitamins of B group and Vitamin C).
  • Each vitamin has a specific function and its deficiency
    leads to a particular deficiency disease.

​Minerals:

  • ​Minerals are the nutrients that are very essential for the proper growth and functioning of our body and are required in small amounts.
  • Calcium, Chlorine, Copper, Fluoride, Iodine, Iron,
    Magnesium, Manganese, Phosphorus, Potassium, Sodium, and Zinc are essential mineral nutrients.

Thus, the nutrients that provide 'protection against diseases' are vitamins and minerals.

Additional Information

  • Energy providing foods:
    • ​​​These are rich in carbohydrates and fats and provide
      the energy for oxidation in the body.
    • Examples of energy-providing food are cereals, sugar, fats, oils, jaggery, etc.
  • Body building foods:
    • ​These are rich in proteins and help in the formation
      of new tissues etc.
    • Examples of body-building food are legumes, milk, egg, meat, fish, pulses, nuts, and oilseeds.

questions.question: Solid&nbsp;food&nbsp;first&nbsp;time&nbsp;added&nbsp;to&nbsp;an&nbsp;infant&rsquo;s&nbsp;diet&nbsp;is&nbsp;called:
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Beikost.

Key Points

  • Definition: Beikost refers to the introduction of semi-solid or solid foods alongside breast milk or formula feeding, marking a significant step in an infant's nutrition and development.
  • Age of Introduction: The World Health Organization (WHO) and many pediatric organizations recommend introducing solids, or beikost, around the age of six months.
  • Complementary Feeding: Beikost is also known as complementary feeding.
  • The term implies that the food is in addition to breast milk or formula, which should remain the primary source of nutrition for the first year.
  • Gradual Process: Introducing beikost is a gradual process, usually starting with pureed fruits, vegetables or, sometimes, iron-fortified cereals.
  • Over time, more texture and variety can be introduced.
  • Importance: This transition is essential to meet the increasing nutritional needs of the growing child.
  • Food Diversity: Over time, a variety of foods should be introduced to ensure the child gets a balanced diet and gets used to different food textures and tastes.
  • Awareness of Allergies: It's important to watch for potential food allergies, particularly when introducing common allergenic foods like eggs, nuts, dairy, and seafood.
  • These foods should be introduced one at a time to pinpoint any potential allergic reactions.
  • Influence on Eating Behavior: How and when beikost is introduced can influence a child's eating behavior and preferences and has implications for their health in later life.
  • Baby-Led Weaning: Another approach to introducing solid food is baby-led weaning, where babies are encouraged to feed themselves hand-held foods instead of being spoon-fed purees.
  • Consultation with Professionals: The introduction of solid foods should be done in consultation with healthcare professionals who can provide appropriate guidance based on the child's growth and development needs.

questions.question: True about&nbsp;complementary feeding is:
options: It can be started from birth with breast feed.
It can be started by 6 months onwards along with breast feed
questions.solution:
Concept:

  • Around the age of 6 months, an infant's need for energy and nutrients starts to exceed what is provided by breast milk, and complementary foods are necessary to meet those needs.
  • A wide range of home-prepared and/or manufactured baby foods broadens the experience of taste and smell at a receptive age.
  • For the 1'st 6 months the children must be given only with breast feeding which we consider as exclusive breast feeding
  • From 6th month onwards breast milk can be started with soft foods which we called as weaning
  • Complimentary feeding must be combined with breast feeding.

Additional Information

  •  Complimentary foods include:-
    • Smashed potatoes
    • Soft dhal with double boiled rice
    • Rice or ragi java etc
  • During this time the infants gastrointestinal system starts developing which can be able to digest the soft foods
  • Foods rich in micronutrients, vitamins and minerals must be given to the children

questions.question: __________ is the main carbohydrate that is easily digested by a newborn.
questions.solution:
Concept:-

  • Carbohydrates are a major component of the daily diet. This type of food contains sugars, starch, and fiber.
  • Carbohydrates are made up of sugar molecules that contain carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen.
  • Lactose is found in milk and milk products (Dairy Products). The body uses an enzyme called lactase which helps in breaking down sugar.

Important Points

  • Lactose is the main carbohydrate present in human milk, providing ~8.5 calories per ounce of human milk.
  • A disaccharide is made up of two simple sugars or monosaccharides. When lactose is broken down, it turns into two simple sugars known as glucose and galactose.
  • Lactose is an interesting disaccharide because infants are able to digest it due to the release of an enzyme called lactase. Lactase breaks the bond between glucose and galactose, both of which can be absorbed into the body.
  • Glucose provides an important source of energy and calories needed for your newborn's growth and development, and galactose contributes to the healthy development of your baby's central nervous system.

questions.question: The main active constituent of tea and coffee is:
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Caffeine.

  • Caffeine is defined as a drug because it stimulates the central nervous system, causing increased alertness.
    • Caffeine gives most people a temporary energy boost and elevates mood.

Caffeine is in tea, coffee, chocolate, many soft drinks, and pain relievers, and other over-the-counter medications.
Additional Information  

  • Caffeine acts as a central nervous system stimulant.
    • When it reaches your brain, the most noticeable effect is alertness.
    • You'll feel more awake and less tired, so it's a common ingredient in medications to treat or manage drowsiness, headaches, and migraines.
    • Caffeine is an alkaloid occurring naturally in some 60 plant species, of which cocoa beans, kola nuts, tea leaves, and coffee beans are the most well-known.
    • Other natural sources of caffeine include yerba maté, guarana berries, guayusa, and the yaupon holly.
    • Caffeine is a stimulant drug, which means it speeds up the messages traveling between the brain and the body.
    • It's found in the seeds, nuts, and leaves of a number of different plants, including Coffea Arabica (used for coffee) and Thea Sinensis (used for tea).

questions.question: A common anthropometric measurement for infants is:
questions.solution:
Concept:-

  • Anthropometric measurement: it is the science of measurement and study of the human body and its parts and capacities.
  • It is the branch of ergonomics that deals with body shape and size.
  • The science of measuring the human body in order to ascertain the average dimensions of the human form at different ages, and in different divisions of race, class, etc.
  • For infants and toddlers who cannot stand, the recumbent length should be measured.

Explanation:-

Recumbent length:

  • it refers to stature taken while lying down. Recumbent length is used to measure infants and children less than two years of age.
  • it is measured from the top of the participant's head to his or her heels while he or she is lying recumbent.

questions.question: The nutritional status is estimated as ______________ based on the measurement of the physical dimensions and gross composition of a person&#39;s body.
questions.solution:
Nutrition Assessment Methods
  • Systems of nutritional assessment may employ a wide variety of specialized methods.

In general, however, these methods fall into five categories:

Dietary assessment

  • Estimation of nutrient intake by assessment of diet, food availability, and food habits (using tools such as food frequency questionnaires, food recall procedures, dietary histories, and food records)

Anthropometric assessment

  • ​​Assessment of nutritional status based on measurements of the physical dimensions and gross composition of a person's body

Clinical assessment

  • Nutritional assessment based on recording medical history and conducting a physical examination to detect signs (observations made by a qualified supervisor) and symptoms (patient-reported manifestations) associated with malnutrition to assess the situation

Biochemical assessment 

  • Assessment of nutritional status based on measurement of nutrient stores, functional forms, excreted forms, and metabolic functions.

Social assessment

  • A collection of non-nutrient-related information known to influence or be related to nutritional status (eg, socioeconomic status, food habits, and beliefs, food prices and availability, food storage, and food cooking practices, drinking water quality, vaccination records, the incidence of low birth weight infants, breastfeeding and weaning practices, age- and cause-specific mortality, birth order, family structure).

questions.question: The correct sequence of periods of child development is :&nbsp;
options: Infancy, Prenatal, Early childhood, Adolescence, Middle childhood
Prenatal, Early childhood, Infancy, Middle childhood, Adolescence
Prenatal, Infancy, Early childhood, Adolescence, Middle childhood
Prenatal, Infancy, Early childhood, Middle childhood, Adolescence
questions.solution:
Child development is the study of how children grow and change physically, cognitively, emotionally, and socially from birth to adulthood.

Key PointsThe following are some of the key stages of child development:

  • Prenatal development (from conception to birth): Prenatal development refers to the development of a child from conception to birth. This is a critical period of development, as the child's physical and neurological structures are forming.
  • Infancy (from birth to 18 months): Infancy is the period of development from birth to 18 months. During this time, infants experience rapid growth and development in all areas, including physical, cognitive, emotional, and social.
  • Early childhood (from 18 months to 5 years): Early childhood is the period of development from 18 months to 5 years. During this time, children continue to grow and develop rapidly, and they begin to learn and explore the world around them.
  • Middle childhood (from 6 to 11 years): Middle childhood is the period of development from 6 to 11 years. During this time, children's physical development slows down, but they continue to learn and grow in cognitive, emotional, and social ways.
  • Adolescence (from 12 to 18 years): Adolescence is the period of development from 12 to 18 years. During this time, adolescents experience major physical, cognitive, emotional, and social changes.

The correct sequence of periods of child development is Prenatal, Infancy, Early Childhood, Middle Childhood, and Adolescence.

questions.question: The process of introducing solid food to an infant is called:
questions.solution:
Concept:

  • Most health experts recommend that babies begin getting solid food at around 4-6 months of age.
  • Six months is often recommended because babies, at this age, begin to need extra nutrients not found in milk, such as iron and zinc.
  • Small amounts of solid food can provide these nutrients.
  • Experts also suggest looking for signs that a baby is developmentally ready for solids. These include:
  • Sitting up well
  • Good head control
  • Can hold food in their mouth and is willing to chew
  • Can pick up food and put it in their mouth
  • Is curious at mealtimes 

Explanation:

  • Weaning ( Dietary Supplements):
  • It is the process by which babies who were fully reliant on milk are introduced to solid foods.
  • It starts with the first mouthful of food and ends with the last feed of breast milk or formula milk.
  • It should be introduced at 6 months.
  • Stages of Introducing Solid fluids:
  • Stage 1: Purees (4 to 6 months).
  • Stage 2: Thicker consistency (6 to 9 months).
  • Stage 3: Soft, chewable chunks (10 to 12 months).

Additional Information

  • Frequency of Feeds:
  • First few weeks: 8-12 times a day during the first few weeks.
  • Demand feeding: 1-4 hours as per demand.
  • By 9-12 months; 3-5 meals.

questions.question: <p>How many calories are there in 1 gram of Fat?</p>
questions.solution:
Concept:

Fat:

  • Fats are also called 'fatty acids' or 'lipids.'
  • Fats in our body are made up of three molecules joined together.
  • This three-molecule structure is called a “triglyceride”.
  • Most of the fat we need is made by our bodies, but there are some fats our bodies cannot make.

Explanation:

  • Fat is one of the macro-nutrients that our body requires for functioning.
  • Along with carbohydrates, protein, and fats are also counted in calories:
    • Carbohydrates: 1g of carbs contains 4 calories,
    • Proteins: 1g of protein contains 4 calories,
    • Fats: 1g of fats contains 9 calories.

Thus, 9 calories are there in 1 gram of fat.

Additional Information: Requirement of macronutrients:

  1. Carbohydrates: 45-65%
  2. Protein: 10-35%
  3. Fat: 20-35%

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of having good personal hygiene?
options: putting on clean clothes after running hard after your soccer game
not taking shower after you play outside in the mud
brushing your teeth once a week
questions.solution:
Concept:

  • Personal hygiene is the practice of taking care of your body and health.
  • Good hygiene is important for cleanliness.
  • Good hygiene prevents illness.

Explanation:

Activities which makes good personal hygiene:

  • Cleaning your body
  • Brushing your teeth every day
  • Wearing neat and clean clothes
  • Covering your mouth while sneezing
  • Use natural deodorants
  • Washing your hands

​Thus, putting on clean clothes after running hard at your soccer game is good personal hygiene.

questions.question: <span style="">Which of the following factors is necessary for a healthy person?</span>
questions.solution:
Concept:

  • Health is defined as a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being.
  • Since health is wealth, effective health maintenance benefits both the body and the mind, as well as the future.
  • When people are healthy, they are more efficient at work.
  • This increases productivity and brings economic prosperity.

Explanation:

Factors necessary for a healthy person are:

  • Balanced diet,
  • Personal hygiene and regular exercise,
  • Awareness about diseases and their effect on different bodily functions,
  • Vaccination (immunisation) against infectious diseases,
  • Proper disposal of wastes,
  • Control of vectors and maintenance of hygiene in food and water resources.

Important PointsVaccination:

  • Vaccines are critical to the prevention and control of infectious disease outbreaks.
  • They help reduce global health security and are a vital tool in the battle against antimicrobial resistance.

Balanced diet:

  • A balanced diet gives your body the nutrients it needs to function correctly. 
  • A person may be getting enough food to eat, but sometimes the food may not contain a particular nutrient.
  • If this continues over a long period of time, the person may suffer from its deficiency.
  • The deficiency of different vitamins and minerals may also result in certain diseases or disorders.
  • All deficiency diseases can be prevented by taking a balanced diet.
  • Some diseases/disorders are caused by a deficiency of vitamins and minerals.

​Personal hygiene:

  • Good hygiene is important for cleanliness.
  • Good hygiene prevents illness.
  • Good hygiene practices are:
    • Brushing teeth daily.
    • Bathing daily.
    • Washing hair regularly.
    • Wearing clean and tidy clothes daily.
    • Keeping rooms clean.
    • Flushing toilets with water after use.
    • Getting nails cut when they grow big.
    • Washing hands before and after eating food.
    • Washing hands with soap after going to the toilet.

Thus, vaccination, a balanced diet, personal hygiene all are the factors necessary for a healthy person.

questions.question: Process of adding vitamins to milk is known as:
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Fortification.

  • Food fortification is the process of adding micronutrients (essential trace elements and vitamins) to food.
  • It is the practice of deliberately increasing the content of an essential micronutrient, i.e. vitamins and minerals (including trace elements) in a food.
  • It is done so as to improve the nutritional quality of the food supply and provide a public health benefit with minimal risk to health.

 Additional Information

  • Flavoring is the extracts, essences, and flavors that are added to foods to enhance their taste and aroma. 
  • Fermentation is a chemical process by which molecules such as glucose are broken down anaerobically (Absence of Oxygen).
  • Sterilization refers to any process that removes, kills, or deactivates all forms of life (in particular referring to microorganisms such as fungi, bacteria, viruses, spores, unicellular eukaryotic organisms such as Plasmodium, etc.).

questions.question: Vitamins and minerals are helpful for which of the following?
options: Carry out metabolic reactions in our body
questions.solution:
The correct answer is to Carry out metabolic reactions in our body. Key Points

  • Vitamins and minerals are essential nutrients that help our body to carry out metabolic reactions.
  • These nutrients are required for the proper functioning of enzymes and hormones that regulate various physiological processes in our body.
  • They also play a crucial role in maintaining the health of our bones, muscles, and immune system.
  • Vitamins and minerals are found in a variety of foods, such as fruits, vegetables, whole grains, dairy products, and lean meats.

Additional Information

  • Proper breathing is mainly regulated by the respiratory system, which involves the lungs, bronchi, and trachea..
  • Sweating is a natural process of the body that helps to regulate body temperature and remove toxins.
  • Fat storage is regulated by various hormones, such as insulin and leptin, that are produced by the endocrine system.

questions.question: Many food preparations are made not by a single method but by a combination of cooking methods. Which of the following is NOT a correct combination cooking method?
options: Meat cutlet : boiling and deep fat frying
questions.solution:
For upma, roasting and frying is not the correct combination of cooking.

Key Points

  • While making upma, the semolina is first lightly roasted.
  • Upma is a healthy dish, usually consumed during breakfast, uses the least amount of oil, only when sauteing vegetables.
  • After that roasted semolina, seasoning, and water is added, no deep frying takes place during its preparation.

Additional Information Upma:

  • Upma is an Indian dish usually consumed in breakfast and has its origin from Southern parts of India like Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka, Tamil Nadu, Kerala, and Telangana.
  • Upma is one of the traditional Indian breakfast recipes made with Rava or semolina.
  • As both upma and suji halwa are made with Rava and water, the difference is one has sugar and the other has vegetables and spices.
  • Upma is prepared using semolina and it is full of iron.
  • Iron is an essential mineral for our body and consuming upma is an easy way of fueling the body with the mineral.
  • Sometimes, upma is also prepared with varagu known as Kodo millet in English, is gluten-free, highly nutritious, fiber-rich, and is very filling.

questions.question: <span style="color: rgb(34, 34, 34);  ">Which method of cooking creates high pressured atmosphere by trapping steam in a airtight vessel?</span>
questions.solution:
• Man has been cooking food since time immemorial, it started when a fire broke accidentally by the ancient man, and the raw meat got roasted in it.
  • When the ancient ate the roasted piece of meat, he likes it and thus cooking of food started.


There are various methods to cook food like:

Moist heat cooking:

  • Moist-heat cooking methods use water, liquid or steam to transfer heat to food.
  • Common moist-heat cooking methods include: poaching, simmering, boiling and steaming.


Pan-broiling:

  • It is a dry cooking method done in a frying pan on top of the stove with no added fat or liquid. 
  • Not only do you not add any fat to the cooking pan, but you also remove any fat as it accumulates.
  • It is the most preferred method of cooking for fish and meat.


Dry heat cooking:

  • Dry heat cooking refers to any cooking technique where the heat is transferred to the food item without using any moisture. 
  • Dry-heat cooking typically involves high heat, with temperatures of 150 °C or hotter. 
  • Baking, grilling, roasting, and frying is a dry heat method because it uses hot air to conduct the heat.


Pressure cooking:

  • Pressure cooking is the process of cooking food under high-pressure steam.
  • Mostly employing water or a water-based cooking liquid, in an airtight vessel known as a pressure cooker.
  • High-pressure limits boiling and permit cooking temperatures well above 100 °C to be reached. 


Thus, the method of cooking that creates high pressured atmosphere by trapping steam in an airtight vessel is pressure cooking.

Combination cooking: 

  • Combination cooking involves both dry- and moist-heat cooking.
  • Braising, stewing and pot-roasting are all combination cooking methods.
  • It is excellent for cooking tougher (but often tastier) cuts of meats.

questions.question: Nutrient retention is high:
questions.solution:
Concept-

  • Grilling and Roasting: These methods help to retain B vitamins, iron, and other nutrients in meat.
  • Nutrient retention is high in various types of food processing and preparation methods. Here are some examples.

    • Microwaving: Though it's often thought to destroy nutrients, microwaving can actually preserve nutrients due to the short cooking times required.

    • Raw foods: Many fruits, vegetables, nuts, and seeds retain high levels of their nutrients when consumed raw, although some nutrients become more available through cooking.

    • Whole Foods: Foods in their whole, unprocessed state typically retain the highest level of nutrients.

    • Freezing: This method can also help to retain nutrients, as it essentially puts them in "suspended animation," locking in their freshness and nutritional value.

    • Short Cooking Times: In general, using short cooking times and minimal amounts of liquid can help to preserve nutrients.

  • Boiling is a method in which food is cooked in enough water. For example boiled potatoes, eggs, rice, and vegetables. Generally: Green leafy vegetables like cabbage, fenugreek, and spinach are cooked without adding extra water.
  • Some vegetables like peas and green beans are cooked by boiling or adding some water. Cereals such as rice and pulses are cooked with a large amount of water (4.5 to 3 times).
  • Boiling causes the greatest loss of nutrients, while other cooking methods preserve the nutrient content of food more effectively. Steaming, roasting, and stir-frying are some of the best ways to cook vegetables when it comes to retaining nutrients.

Important Points

Following are some of the points to be kept in mind while boiling food:

  • Food should be thoroughly cleaned before boiling. The water should be enough to cover the food item completely.
  • Cook food in a vessel whose lid closes tightly. By this method, the steam will not go out from the boiling water and the water will not dry up. This cooks the food faster and the process also saves fuel.
  • Food should not be boiled for longer than necessary. As soon as the food becomes soft and chewy, it should be taken off the heat. If food is boiled for a long time, its color, shape, and taste are lost. This also destroys the nutritional properties of the food.
  • Potatoes and other root vegetables should be boiled along with their skins so that their nutritional properties can be preserved.

questions.question: Which of the following is the advantage of microwave cooking?
options: Food is cooked in its own juices, so its flavor is retained
questions.solution:
Food is cooked in its own juices, so its flavor is retained is one of the advantage of microwave cooking.

Key PointsMicrowave cooking:

Definition: Microwave cookery is cooking or reheating food using electromagnetic waves in a microwave oven powered by electricity. Microwaves activate the water molecules or particles of food, causing heat by friction which cooks or reheats the food.

Advantages:

  • Very fast method of cooking
  • Fast method of defrosting
  • Economical on electricity and labour
  • Food is cooked in its own juices, so its flavour is retained
  • Minimises food shrinkage and drying-out

 

Disadvantages:

  • Not suitable for all foods
  • Limited space
  • Can only penetrate 5 cm into food (from all sides)

 

Examples of foods which might be cooked by microwave:

  • Farinaceous (pasta) -
  • Fish (trout, salmon) -
  • Vegetables (potatoes) -
  • Pre-cooked meals

questions.question: What is the primary objective of the Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI) in establishing a network of 34 microbiology labs across the country?
options: To promote the consumption of organic food products
To test food products for 10 pathogens, including E coli, salmonella and listeria.
To conduct research on traditional Indian cooking methods
To regulate the export of Indian food products
questions.solution:
The Correct Answer is To test food products for 10 pathogens, including E coli, salmonella and listeria.

In News

  • FSSAI sets up lab network to test food for pathogens.

Key Points

  •  With food poisoning and diarrhoea becoming a common occurrence, the Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI) is working towards creating a network of 34 microbiology labs across the country that will be equipped to test food products for 10 pathogens, including E coli, salmonella and listeria.
  • These labs will help test food for microbial contamination that can lead to spoilage of food and potential health risks.
  • These labs will be able to test the food samples collected during routine surveillance for microbes now.
  • FSSAI was established on 5 September 2008 under Food Safety and Standards Act, 2006 which was operationalized in year 2006.
  • The FSSAI consists of a chairperson & 22 members.

questions.question: All food that are to be held cold must be held at ______ or below temperature.
questions.solution:
All food that is to be held cold must be held at 41° F or below temperature.

Key Points 

  • All food, especially TCS foods should be held cold at 41° F or below this temperature because these are highly perishable foods.
  • By failing so, microbial spoilage will occur readily and leads to microbial food spoilage.
  • That’s why it’s critical to control temperatures and reduce the amount of time that food is exposed to the hot zone – temperatures between 41° F and 135° F.
  • Higher and lower temperatures retard or stop bacteria from growing.

questions.question: Which of the following is the preferred method of thawing potentially hazardous foods?
questions.solution:
Thawing of potentially hazardous foods is preferred in the refrigerator.

Key Points

  • Potentially hazardous foods are perishable foods that have the highest water content and are more prone to spoilage.
  • Due to high water content, the freezing and thawing should be done very carefully because there are chances of tissue damage.
  • Perishable foods must never be thawed at room temperature.
  • It should be always placed in a refrigerator first.
  • Frozen food items should be thawed safely with the use of coolers or refrigerators set at a temperature of 41°F or below.
  • As they are stored in this type of environment, they can safely thaw while remaining in the proper range of temperatures for cold holding of food until time to be cooked.

questions.question: What is the group of hydrocarbon gasses like propane, butane, isobutene, referred to as?
questions.solution:
Liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) mainly consists of hydrocarbon gasses like propane, butane, isobutene.

Key Points

Liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), also called cooking gas, is a flammable mixture of hydrocarbon gases used as fuel in heating appliances, cooking equipment, and vehicles.

Additional Information

  • Butane is a colorless, odorless, gaseous hydrocarbon. Its chemical formula is C4H10. 
  • Ethyne is also known as acetylene. It is an organic chemical compound with the chemical formula C2H2.
  • Propane is a flammable hydrocarbon gas that is liquefied through pressurization and is commonly used for fuel in heating, cooking, and vehicles.
  • Ethene is a gaseous by-product of the process of cracking of long-chain hydrocarbons.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a principle of growth and development?
options: The rate of growth and development are the same.
questions.solution:
The correct answer is the rate of growth and development are the same.

Key Points

  • Growth and Development are inseparable but they differ from each other.
  • The growth represents the physical changes of an individual and development represents the overall changes, structure and shape of an individual.
  • Principles of Growth and Development are:
    • Principle of Continuity
    • Principle of integration
    • Principle of lack of uniformity in the development rate
    • Principle of individual difference
    • Principle of unifromity pattern
    •  Principle of moving from General to Specific
    • Principle of interaction between Heredity and Environment
    • Principle of interrelation
    • Principle of Cephalocaudal
    • Principle of Proximodistal
    • Principle of Predictability
    • Principle of Spiral versus Linear advancement
    • Principle of Association of Maturation and Learning

 Thus, we can say that the same rate of growth and development is not a principle of growth and development.

questions.question: Human growth and development is influenced by
questions.solution:
• Development refers to a qualitative change that results in an increase in structure for better and enhanced functioning of organs.
  • Growth refers to a quantitative change that results in an increase in height, weight, and length of the child.

Key Points

Human growth and development is influenced by both 'Hereditary and Environment' as they are the elements that play a vital role in determining the development of an individual.

  • All mental and social traits depend on the environment.
  • All the inborn traits, instincts, and I. Q. depend on heredity.
  • All the potential inputs for growth and development depend on heredity.
  • Both are complementary to each other in molding the life of an individual.
  • How a person will develop depends on the environment but how far a person can develop depends on heredity.
  • Heredity places limit on IQ and the environment determines the numeric position of IQ within these limits.

Hence it could be concluded that human growth and development is influenced by both 'Hereditary and Environment'.

Important Points

  • Heredity: It refers to the traits that pass down from the parents to their offspring. It is the most important personality and intelligence determinant.
  • Environment: It refers to the circumstances in which an individual lives. Child's immediate environment strongly influenced their personality and intelligence.

questions.question: Docking is a term best related to which method of cookery?
questions.solution:
Docking is a term best related to baking.

Key PointsDefinition of docking: A pie or tart crust is docked, by pricking it all over with a fork, to allow steam to exit while the crust is baking. This helps prevent the crust from puffing up and shrinking.

When docking is used: Docking can be used instead of baking a crust with pie weights. However, it is best used for pies and tarts that will not have a very liquid filling.

Additional InformationRoasting: roasting is a cooking method in which dry heat is used, where hot air covers the food cooking it evenly. During roasting temperature reaches up to 150° C.

Microwave: It is a device that uses microwave radiation to heat the food which is kept under it. The microwave oven operates at a frequency of 2450 MHz.

Poêlé: It is a french word meaning stove. The stove is generally connected either by gas connection or it works on induction and is used for cooking food in utensils like frying pan, woks, etc.

questions.question: How can a hostel encourage a healthy and balanced diet among its residents?
options: Offering a limited and monotonous menu with unhealthy food options
Providing a wide variety of nutritious meals and promoting healthy eating habits
Discouraging students from using the hostel's dining facilities
Allowing students to bring outside food without any restrictions
questions.solution:
Diet is an important part of everyone’s life as it regulates the functioning of the body.
Key Points 
  • A healthy diet is necessary for the residents of the hostel as it will support their mental and physical development.
  • A balanced diet that includes all the micro and macro nutrients is essential as it regulates the effective functioning of the body.
  • They promote a healthy diet in the hostel following steps can be taken:
    • Nutritious Meal Options: Offer a variety of nutritious meal options in the hostel cafeteria or kitchenette, including salads, fruits, vegetables, lean proteins, and whole grains.
    • Nutrition Education: Host workshops or seminars on nutrition and healthy eating habits to educate residents about making better food choices.
    • Healthy Snack Choices: Stock vending machines and common areas with healthy snack options like nuts, yogurt, and fresh fruit.
    • Nutritional Information: Display nutritional information and calorie counts for food items in the cafeteria or kitchenette.
    • Meal Plans: Offer flexible meal plans that cater to different dietary preferences and restrictions, such as vegetarian, vegan, or gluten-free options.

To conclude, Providing a wide variety of nutritious meals and promoting healthy eating habits encourages students to healthy diet.

questions.question: Identify a way that does NOT prevent a non-communicable disease from occurring in someone.
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Blood transfusion

Key Points

  • Non-communicable diseases are chronic health conditions that are not contagious and, tend to be of long duration and are the result of a combination of genetic, physiological, environmental and behavioural factors
  • Blood transfusions are used for patients who have experienced serious injuries from car crashes or natural disasters.

Additional Information

  • A balanced diet is a diet that contains differing kinds of foods in certain quantities and amount.
  • A healthy diet includes the following: Fruit, vegetables, legumes (e.g. lentils and beans), nuts, and whole grains (e.g. unprocessed maize, millet, oats, wheat, and brown rice.
  • Adequate Sleep, is the amount of sleep is an important indicator of health and well-being in children and adolescents.

questions.question: Nutritional deficiency in childhood (0-6) can cause:
questions.solution:
Good nutrition has an important role in growth and development. As children enter school age, their nutritional needs increase. In fact, there are differences in the nutrient requirements of boys and girls from the age of 10 years. 

Malnutrition and infections are interrelated. In fact, malnutrition is a national problem. It is a consequence of several factors such as illiteracy, poverty, ignorance about the nutritional needs of children, and poor access to health care, especially in rural and tribal areas.

Important Points

Nutritional deficiency diseases may set in at this stage if the infant is not exclusively breastfed and when complementary foods do not meet the nutrient needs of infants. Nutritional deficiency at this stage can result in lifelong impairments and disabilities. On the other hand, adequate nutrition ensures that the children grow to their full potential. Let us list the important deficiency diseases that may occur in childhood precisely.

  • Protein Energy Malnutrition (PEM): leads to growth retardation and infections leading to diarrhea and dehydration
  • Anemia: caused due to iron deficiency 
  • Nutritional blindness: results due to vitamin A deficiency
  • Rickets and osteopenia are bone-related: due to shortage of vitamin D and calcium
  • Goiter (enlargement of the thyroid gland): due to deficiency of Iodine

Hence, we can conclude that nutritional deficiency in early childhood can cause Nutritional blindness.

questions.question: Recently seen in news, the concept of &ldquo;5Fs&rdquo; crisis &ndash; Food, Feed, Fuel, Fertilisers, and Finance, is devised by&nbsp;
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Option 2.

In News

  • 53% of women in India aged between 15 to 49 had anemia, which was the largest prevalence rate in the region in 2019.
  • “It (anemia) impairs health and well-being in women and increases the risk for adverse maternal and neonatal outcomes.

questions.question: How does a child&#39;s lower health and nutritional value (0-3 years old) affect him?
questions.solution:
The first three years of life are a crucial period for brain development. During this time, the brain forms trillions of neural connections, establishing the foundation for cognitive skills like memory, language, problem-solving, and critical thinking.

Key PointsPoor health and nutritional deficiencies can negatively impact these critical brain development processes. This can lead to:

  • Delayed cognitive development: Children may reach developmental milestones like speech and communication skills later than expected.
  • Learning difficulties: They may struggle with learning in school, facing challenges with reading, writing, and math.
  • Attention and focus issues: Difficulties with concentration and remembering information can hinder learning and social interactions.
  • Behavioral problems: Poorly controlled emotions, impulsive actions, and social withdrawal might be observed.

Hence, considering the critical role of early brain development and the detrimental effects of malnutrition and poor health on this process, impaired cognitive learning is the most accurate answer.

questions.question: &ldquo;Nutrient&rdquo; means a constituent of food, which ________-
options: Has specific metabolic or physiological functions
Is needed for growth and development and maintenance of healthy life
questions.solution:
“Nutrient” means a constituent of food, which-

  1. Provides energy.
  2.  Has specific metabolic or physiological functions.
  3. Is needed for growth and development and maintenance of healthy life.

Additional InformationNutrition claims may be-

  1. Nutrient content claim.
  2. Nutrient comparative claim.

“nutrient content claim”

  • This is a nutrition claim that directly or indirectly describes the level of a nutrient contained in a food.
  • Examples: contains or source of; high in; rich in; low in, etc.

“nutrient comparative claim”

  • This is a claim that compares the nutrient levels or energy value of two or more foods.
  • Examples: reduced; less than; fewer; increased; more than, etc.

questions.question: World Hand Hygiene Day is observed every year on ______ May.&nbsp;
questions.solution:
Explanation

  • Hand hygiene is a way of cleaning one's hands that substantially reduces potential pathogens (harmful microorganisms) on the hands.
  • Hand hygiene is considered a primary measure for reducing the risk of transmitting infection among patients and health care personnel.
  • Hand Hygiene Day is Celebrated every year on 5 May.
  •  World Hand Hygiene Day (WHHD) theme for 2022 is a “health care quality and safety climate or culture”.
  • Steps of performing hand hygiene

​

 

Additional Information Five movements of hand hygiene

  • Before touching a patient;
  • Before clean/aseptic procedures;
  • After body fluid exposure/risk;
  • After touching a patient; and
  • After touching the patient's surroundings

questions.question: Which of the following Hygiene Rating Initiative?
questions.solution:
FSSAI introduced Hygiene Rating scheme for:

  • Initiative 1: Restaurants and Catering establishments
  • Meat shops (Initiative 2: Clean and Safe Meat Shops)
  • Mithai shops (initiative 3: Clean and Safe Mithai Shops)

Key Points

 Hygiene Rating (HR) 

  • ​​Technology-enabled, user-friendly scheme.
  • Individual food service establishments were given a "Star rating" for their hygiene and food safety compliance.
  • Certification is valid for two years.

Additional Information

"Star rating":

  • Given in the range of 1 to 5
  • This indicates how the food is prepared, handled, and served safely and hygienically. 
  • It assists consumers in making choices to find out the best food premises.

questions.question: How many moments of hand hygiene have been laid down by WHO?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

5 Moments for Hand Hygiene according to WHO.


Confusion Points

  • There is a difference between “Moments of Hand Hygiene” and Steps of Hand Hygiene.
  • The 5 Moments for Hand Hygiene defines the key Incidences or situations when health care workers must demonstrate hand hygiene.
  • The key to hand washing with 7 Steps of Hand Washing is to ensure that you thoroughly clean all surfaces and areas of your hands, fingers, and wrists.

questions.question: They play an important role in the regulation of the metabolic activity in the body and help in utilisation of the proximate principles:
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Vitamins and Minerals.

Key Points

  • Vitamins and minerals, collectively known as micronutrients, have diverse biochemical roles that contribute to the functioning of many metabolic reactions and processes in the body.
  • Vitamins:
  1. These are organic compounds that cannot be synthesized by humans in sufficient quantity and hence, need to be supplied through the diet.
  2. They are classified into two groups: fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, and K) and water-soluble vitamins (C and B vitamins like thiamine, riboflavin, niacin, pantothenic acid, B6, biotin, folic acid, and B12).
  3. For instance, B vitamins are critical in the conversion of food (carbohydrates, fats, and proteins) into energy.
  4. They aid in the digestion process and the production of energy by acting as coenzymes that work with enzymes to break down food.
  5. Vitamins A, C, and E also function as antioxidants, neutralizing harmful free radicals that can damage cells and lead to chronic disease.
  • Minerals:
  1. These are inorganic nutrients that also play a crucial role in several body functions.
  2. They are classified as macrominerals (required in larger amounts, like calcium, phosphorus, and magnesium) and trace minerals (required in smaller amounts, but still essential, like iron, zinc, selenium, etc.).
  3. Minerals like calcium and phosphorus are vital for bone health.
  4. Iron is essential for the production of hemoglobin, a protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen throughout the body.
  5. Minerals like magnesium and potassium are essential for muscle contraction and nerve transmission.

questions.question: The lungs are part of which system?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • We have two lungs that are covered by a double-layered pleura, with pleural fluid between them.
  • It reduces friction on the lung surface.
  • The Respiratory System consists of a series of organs responsible for taking in oxygen and expelling carbon dioxide.
  • These organs are the nose, pharynx, larynx, trachea, bronchi, lungs, and alveoli.
  • Respiration is an exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide in our bodies.

Important Points

  • Respiration is the stepwise oxidation of glucose (and other nutrients) which results in the release of energy that is stored in the cytosol in the form of ATP (adenosine triphosphate).
  • Whenever energy is required by our body, ATP is broken down and a large amount of energy is released.

Thus, the lungs are a part of the respiratory system.

Additional Information Other important organ systems in the body are:

Nervous system:

  • The neural system coordinates and integrates functions as well as metabolic and homeostatic activities of all the organs.
  • The human neural system consists of two parts :
    • (i) the central neural system (CNS) and
    • (ii) the peripheral neural system (PNS).
  • The CNS consists of the brain and spinal cord. 

Digestive system:

  • The digestive system of humans consists of an alimentary canal and associated digestive glands.
  • The alimentary canal consists of the mouth, buccal cavity, pharynx, esophagus, stomach, small intestine, large
    intestine, rectum, and anus.
  • The accessory digestive glands include the salivary glands, the liver (with gall bladder) and the pancreas.

questions.question: Biological value used to measure quality of:
questions.solution:
Concept:

Biological value:

  • It is defined as the proportion of protein retained in the body for growth and maintenance and expressed in the per cent of nitrogen absorbed.
  • Biological value is the value that tells us how efficiently the body has absorbed the protein from the consumption through the diet.

Explanation:

​Protein:

  • Protein is a polymer of amino acids.
  • Dietary proteins are the source of essential amino acids.
  • Proteins carry out many functions in living organisms such as transporting nutrients across the cell membrane.
  • Protein also helps in fighting infectious organisms.

Thus, biological value is used to measure the quality of proteins.

Additional Information 

Carbohydrates:

  • Carbohydrates are the source of energy for the body of living beings.
  • Some common examples of carbohydrates are cane sugar, glucose, starch, etc.

​Vitamins:

  • Vitamins are accessory food factors required in the diet.
  • They are classified as fat-soluble (A, D, E, and K) and water-soluble (Β group and C).

Fat:

  • Fat is an important macronutrient.
  • It is also an important part of the diet for all animals and humans.
  • Body stores fat for protection, warmth, and energy.
  • Different types of fats, which are saturated and unsaturated, keep our bodies healthy in different ways.

questions.question: The substances that control the internal activities of the body are-
questions.solution:
Concept:

Nutrients:

  • The food we consume breaks down to simpler products before it is absorbed and utilised by the body.
  • These simpler substances are called nutrients.
  • The human body utilises nutrients for building and repairing, obtaining energy and for protection from disease.

Explanation:

Vitamin:

  • Vitamins are organic substances that we require in adequate quantities for good health.
  • Our body, cannot synthesise them.
  • Therefore, we need to consume natural sources such as fruits and vegetables.
  • Vitamins are divided into two groups–fat-soluble vitamins (Vitamins A, D, E, and K) and water-soluble vitamins (Vitamins of B group and Vitamin C).
  • The body's internal processes are under vitamin control.
  • Each vitamin has a specific function and its deficiency leads to a particular deficiency disease.

Thus, the substances that control the internal activities of the body are vitamins.

Additional Information

Fat:

  • Fats and oils are concentrated sources of energy.
  • Fats are substances that our body stores for future use.
  • These are classified as simple lipids, compound lipids, and derived lipids.
  • Fats may be obtained from animal or vegetable sources.

Mineral-Phosphorus:

  • Minerals are the nutrients that are very essential for the proper growth and functioning of our body and are required in small amounts. 
  • Phosphorus is an essential mineral nutrient.
  • It helps in the Development of strong bones, and teeth; making energy-rich compounds in cells.

Protein:

  • Proteins are called building blocks of our body.
  • About 20 per cent of our body weight comes from proteins.
  • Proteins are essential for the growth and repair of muscle and other body tissues.
  • Proteins are made of amino acids.
  • Humans obtain proteins from animal as well as vegetable sources.

questions.question:
Read the following passage and answer the questions:

The wastage of food is substantial in every country, but some studies have shown that it is more serious in developing countries. The UNFAO had estimated that one-third of all produced food may be getting wasted. The world produces twice the amount of food that is needed, but large numbers of people are deprived of it due to wastage and other reasons. Food gets wasted at the farm, when it moves to the market and is processed, stored and shifted to shops and finally in the kitchen. Many fruits and vegetables perish soon after harvesting. There is a need to improve production and storage practices, transport infrastructure, cold chain systems and processing techniques. Modern technologies and better packaging methods are needed. But even in countries where these facilities are available, wastage is high. So, the most important requirement is to improve popular awareness of the need to ensure that food is not wasted in any form, at any stage. Some countries have launched a clean plate campaign against wastage of food. It is estimated that food worth at least Rs. 1 lakh crore is wasted in India, and this does not include wastage of cooked food. A part of that should be enough to feed the large numbers of hungry people in the country, which is ranked 94 out of 107 countries in the Global Hunger Index. Food is wasted massively at weddings and on other occasions. The UN report says that reducing food waste would also cut green house gas emissions and slow the destruction of nature through land conversion and pollution. Avoiding food wastage should therefore become a national mission. It will have very positive environmental, social and economic impacts. Let us remember that millions of families go hungry every day in many parts of the world. In India. the household food waste estimate is 50 kg per capita per year, which is less than the US and China. But this may not be because of more efficient use of food, but because overall availability is less.

The world produces more food, but a large number of people are deprived of it because of
questions.solution:
The correct answer is "Multi-point wastage"

Key Points

  • Let's consider the following statement from the above passage.
    • The world produces twice the amount of food that is needed, but large numbers of people are deprived of it due to wastage and other reasons. 
    • Food gets wasted at the farm, when it moves to the market and is processed, stored and shifted to shops and finally in the kitchen.
  • From the above statements it is clear that the  world produces more food, but a large number of people are deprived of it because of Multi-point wastage.

Therefore the correct answer is Option 2.

questions.question:
Direction: Read the passage and answer the questions that follow.

Vegans try to live, as much as possible, in a way that avoids exploiting and being cruel to animals. This means following a plant-based diet. Vegans do not eat animals or animal-based products like meat, fish, seafood, eggs, honey and dairy products such as cheese Vegetarians don’t eat meat or fish but they can eat eggs, honey, and dairy products, but vegans don’t eat any animal-based food products. The sixth-century BC Greek mathematician and philosopher Pythagoras was in favour of kindness to all species For many people, the main reason for going vegan is probably that they believe that animals and all other sentient beings should have the right to life and freedom. However, there are other reasons. On 1 November every year, vegans all over the world celebrate their way of life. What kind of diet is taken by vegans?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is - Plant-based diet.
Key Points

  • The given passage is about Vegans and how a vegan diet is different from vegetarian and non-vegetarian.
  • Let us refer to the passage - Vegans try to live, as much as possible, in a way that avoids exploiting and being cruel to animals. This means following a plant-based diet. ​

From the above line, we can say that: Vegan takes a plant-based diet.

questions.solution:
The correct answer is- Conscious.

  •  The given passage is about Vegans and how a vegan diet is different from vegetarian and non-vegetarian.
  • Sentient(adjective): Able to experience feelings.
    • Example: It is hard for a sentient person to understand how any parents could treat their child so badly.
  • Conscious(adjective): aware of and responding to one's surroundings.
    • Example: He gradually became conscious that everyone else was wearing a suit.

From the above, we can say that Conscious is a synonym of sentient.
Additional Information

  • Let us explore other option:
  • Ignorant(adjective): Not having enough knowledge, understanding, or information about something.
  • Oblivious(adjective): Not conscious of something, especially what is happening around you.
  • Unconscious(adjective): In the state of not being awake and not aware of things around you, especially as the result of a head injury.
